Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Evolutionary trade-offs in the adaptation of decomposers to global warming: Implications for ecosystem C balance
Award.AbstractNarration:
Soil fungi responsible for the decay and recycling of carbon may evolve in response to global warming. This could have serious consequences with respect to global change. This team of investigators posit that warmer temperatures may favor the evolution of fungi that can break down material that is long-lived(?recalcitrant?) in the soil . As a consequence, more greenhouse gases would be released to the atmosphere in a feedback loop that could lead to even warmer temperatures. This issue is particularly urgent in the northern, boreal forests of Alaska, which store large amounts of recalcitrant matter in their soils, and which are warming more rapidly than elsewhere. Research team members will be simulating global warming in such forests and examining its effects on fungi and their degradation activities. In addition, they will be exposing fungi to warming in laboratory experiments that will use genetic and physiological tests to examine how their ability to decompose recalcitrant materials changes over time.

Human life cannot exist without fungi to decompose organic matter, since they recycle nutrients from dead organisms for use by plants, animals, and people. This study will provide explicit predictions of the different ways that global warming maybe affecting fungi. It will also be one of the first to examine the evolution of these microbes in response to global warming. In addition, the investigators will train one postdoctoral researcher, two graduate students and several undergraduate researchers, with an emphasis on recruitment of students from underrepresented groups in science. The investigators will also invite students and teachers from a nearby elementary school to participate in day-long mushroom forays and a global change field trip.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This short article reports the outcomes from research designed to improve our understanding of global change.  Our civilization requires energy and our use of carbon stored deep in the Earth as coal, oil and gas has added enough carbon dioxide to the atmosphere to cause a rise in the Earth’s temperature.  A lot of carbon also is stored in surface soil, three times as much as in air, and much of the soil carbon is found in northern areas, like the Boreal Forest in Alaska. This soil carbon is made from dead plants and it remains in the soil because few life forms can consume this recalcitrant carbon. Foremost among the organisms that can consume recalcitrant carbon are fungi, which, along with plants and animals, is one of the three big kingdoms of complex life forms.  As you probably have guessed by now, the question driving our research is this: As our Earth warms, will fungi metabolize more of this stored carbon and move it from the soil to the atmosphere, thereby exacerbating the problem of global change by increasing the amount of atmospheric carbon dioxide?

 

As the Earth warms, the natural world will react, soil fungi included. Soil fungi in the Boreal Forest could acclimate or evolve to function at higher temperatures, or they could migrate from warmer areas where they already have evolved to live in a warmer environment. To address our questions, we chose a species of fungus known to digest plants that is distributed throughout North America and beyond, Neurospora discreta.  

 

The outcomes of our NSF-supported research are the result of collaborations between scientists at two campuses of the University of California, Irvine and Berkeley. This core group had help from scientists at the Universities of New Mexico and Alaska, as well as French researchers. The first outcome is that fungi best adapted to high temperatures are found in two branches of the tree of life, the Eurotiomycetes (where Penicillium, the fungus that makes penicillin is found) and the Sordariomycetes (where Neurospora is found). The second outcome is that Neurospora discreta is a complex of about 10 species and the one that we studied, Neurospora discreta 4b, has three lineages, one in Alaska, a second in the Sierra Nevada-Cascade Mountains and a third in the Rocky Mountains.  The third outcome is that Neurospora from Alaska adapted to higher temperatures by growing slower but respiring faster, probably because it put more resources into reproducing. The fourth outcome is that the enzymes that Neurospora exports to digest soil carbon, which we thought would digest more effectively as temperatures warmed, did not necessarily do so. Neither did enzymes from fungi native to warmer climates necessarily perform better as temperatures increased. The fifth outcome is that Neurospora is not as good at digesting recalcitrant soil carbon as we expected. Based on these outcomes, it may be that the largest effect on microbial activity in areas of abundant, soil carbon will not be acclimation or evolution, but immigration of fungi from warmer, southern areas.  The outcomes also inform our ideas for future research, including searches for fungi that are both good model organisms and effective consumers of recalcitrant soil carbon.  Perhaps the most important outcome is that fungi are being included in the models designed to predict the magnitude of global change, which was impossible just a few years ago.
